commitResults.messageBody: This is for the clarity of the printAll() method implemented in the TaskHistory class

commitResults.messageTitle: Adjust coding style for switch-case apllication in Duke.java
commitResults.messageBody: To adhere to the java coding standard set for this iP.

commitResults.messageTitle: Duke class: Update Duke's response to "invalid keywords"
commitResults.messageBody:
Duke's response to "invalid keywords" is to print a list of
recognized keywords that the user can use.

Updating the response will teach users the keywords they can use to
access the latest features of Duke.

Let's update the printed response to correctly reflect the current
list of recognized keywords.

commitResults.messageTitle: Commands class: add startup() method
commitResults.messageBody:
There does not exist a way for us to detect if ./data/duke.txt is a
valid file path that exists.

In order for us to implement our "save" feature in Duke, we require
./data/duke.txt to exist so we can update the duke.txt file after
each update by the user.

Let's implement a startup() method that is called at the beginning
of each session with Duke that checks for and creates the data
folder and duke.txt file.

This is so we can easily bug fix this startup() method in the future
in the case of any poor implementation.

The startup() method currently implemented is only able to check for
the existence of a folder named "data" in the root folder containing
Duke.java.

commitResults.messageTitle: Commands class: update startup() method
commitResults.messageBody:
startup() method is only capable of checking the existence of a
"data" directory in the root directory containing the Duke program.

This is only a means to determine if there is a need to manually
create the directory for future use.

Let's now provide an independent path to contain our duke.txt file
and also create the parent directory, child directory and duke.txt
file if it does not already exist.

startup() now creates a folder and duke.txt file that will be used
to keep track of a users task history.

The specific path used is "C:\Users\username\Duke\data". The main
method in Duke.java has also been updated to call startup() at the
beginning of each session.

commitResults.messageTitle: Commands class: add restore() method
commitResults.messageBody:
There does not exist a way for users to reuse a previously created
local copy of duke.txt.

This does not fulfil one of the features of Duke that we are trying
to implement. We want to be able to load the data from the hard disk
when Duke starts up

Let's now provide a way to load the contents of an existing duke.txt
file onto a session of Duke.

By creating a restore() method that takes in a File object as
argument, we are able to customize how Duke handles a custom
duke.txt script. This gives us the flexibility to format the
duke.txt file for our convenience.

To facilitate the implementation of restore(), we want to have
special constructors for the Todo, Deadline and Event classes that
can allow us to create tasks based on the information stored on the
duke.txt file.

Lastly, we also want to provide methods to add these tasks on the
duke.txt file in the background without interfering with the current
session of duke. This is done by overloading the add"" methods in
the Commands class

commitResults.messageTitle: Commands class: add update() method
commitResults.messageBody:
There does not exist a way for users to manually request Duke to
store the data of the current session onto their local device.

We want to provide the flexibility to our users to manually request
Duke to store the data of their current session. We also need a way
to trigger this storing of data when Duke is closed so this is a
step towards that.

Let's now provide a way to request Duke to update the local duke.txt
file with the latest records stored in Duke for the current session.

By creating a update() method, we are able to call for the update in
our code and also provide a way for the user to manually request for
this update without having to close Duke.

The ToDos, Deadline and Event classes have been provided methods to
help with update(). Also, a new keyword "update" is recognized by
Duke.

commitResults.messageTitle: Duke class: update "bye" keyword behavior
commitResults.messageBody:
Previously, we do not get Duke to update the local duke.txt file at
the end of a session.

If the user forgets to call "update" manually, the data created
or changed during the session is not saved.

Let's make it so that Duke will automatically save data to the user
hard disk by calling update() when "bye" keyword is used.

commitResults.messageTitle: Duke class: add isDateValid() method
commitResults.messageBody:
For keywords "deadline" and "event", Duke interprets the date & time
arguments provided as Strings and stores them word for word in it's
records.

We want to provide users with a more uniform response when it comes
to date & time such that any provided input will give the same
output.

Let's first introduce a method to validate date formats so we can
teach Duke different date formats and get it to recognize them.

We want to create a method that we can expand on in the future,
adding new date formats for Duke to recognize.

Currently, the method only has 2 date formats that it recognizes and
does not validate time.

commitResults.messageTitle: Duke class: change isDateValid() method to convertToDukeDate() method
commitResults.messageBody:
isDateValid() returned a boolean that indicated if Duke recognized
the given date format or not.

This boolean needed to be handled separately outside of
isDateValid() before Duke will process the given date into a uniform
format.

Let's change the isDateValid() method into a method that immediately
does the conversion as well and returns a LocalDate object.

This gives as a more useful object to manipulate accordingly in our
other methods in the Commands class.

convertToDukeDate() has been moved from Duke.java to Commands.java
where it will be better used. Both "deadline" and "event" keywords
have had their implementations updated to include the use of
convertToDukeDate().

commitResults.messageTitle: Duke class: add convertToDukeTime()
commitResults.messageBody:
Duke currently treats time as a String and does not manipulate it in
any way.

We want Duke to be able to convert time inputs in 24-hour format to
a standardized output.

Let's implement a new method convertToDukeTime() that does this.

This gives us the flexibility to detect and convert 24-hour time
to 12-hour time for any commands that expect a time input from the
user.

"deadline" and "event" keywords have been updated to call
convertToDukeTime() when needed.

commitResults.messageTitle: Duke class: update Duke to save state after every command
commitResults.messageBody:
Duke currently only saves the state to the user's local hard drive
on request ("update") or at the end of a session.

This could led to potential lost of user data if an expected crash
leading to an unexpected end to the session without the user or
Duke invoking the update() command.

Let's make it so that Duke will automatically try to update the
local duke.txt file after every command.

We are simply adding a update() call after every keyword call.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix bugs from merging branch-Level-8
Add more OOP components (DukeUi, DukeStorage and DukeHistory)
Move related files to duke package
Add DukeTest.java for unit testing of Duke.
Add Gradle support with build.gradle
Add javaDocs comment for all methods in subclasses used by the main program.
Adjust code to adhere to coding standard.
Duke package: add support for "find" keyword.
commitResults.messageBody:
The only way for users to view the records in Duke during a session
is to use the "list" keyword.

This is inefficient and provides very little flexibility when it
comes to viewing records.

Let's add a feature that allows the user to view all tasks in Duke's
records according to a specified word or phrase.

We will implement a new keyword "find" that takes in a phrase, looks
through duke's history and returns a list of all tasks that has that
phrase in their description.

Support for "find" keyword has been added in subclasses supporting
the Duke package in the form of:
Commands class: add find() method
DukeHistory class: add findPhrase() method
DukeUi class: add printFoundNothing() method

Add GUI support using javafx.

commitResults.messageTitle: Duke.java: assertions used so define assumptions so that the runtime can verify them.
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, Duke is manually ensuring that all inputs have the right
number of tokens to ensure that the keywords used are provided the
appropriate amount of arguments.

This is inefficient and makes our code lengthier as a result.

We want to make use of java assert to verify these basic assumptions
rather then write specific if-else statements to handle this during
runtime.

Assert it a in-built function of Java that we can use to shorten our
code while still achieving the desired outcome.

As much as possible, all keywords are now asserting assumptions and
changes can be found within the run() method of Duke.java.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update codeQuality branch.
commitResults.messageBody:
Create byeCommand, listCommand, markCommand,
unmarkCommand, todoCommand and deadlineCommand classes.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update codeQuality.
commitResults.messageBody:
Add implementation to byeCommand, listCommand, markCommand,
unmarkCommand, todoCommand and deadlineCommand classes.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update code Quality. Add DeleteCommand, EventCommand, FindCommand and UpdateCommand.
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently Command class, DukeHistory class and Duke class have been
sharing the work of dealing with all valid Duke Commands.

This has caused the overall code to be excessively long and
unreadable.

Let's update the code quality of Duke. Specifically, let's lessen
the burden on the above mentioned classes when handling valid
Commands. We will implement specific sub-Command classes that
inherit from the Commands class and offload all the code logic to
those classes. We will strive towards SLAP in our implementation.

This is so our code becomes shorter and much more readable.

The past 2 commits has added the other sub-Command classes. Also the
GUI has been fixed so that it now displays the full output without
truncating the String.
